facts: Habitat: Dry, open hillsides and meadows
Native Status: Native to the Rocky Mountain region
Interesting Fact: Entire plant is edible and was used by Indigenous peoples
Best Seen: Lamar Valley and near Mammoth in early summer
Growth Habit: Perennial with deep taproot
Leaf Shape: Large, arrow-shaped basal leaves
Habitat: Moist meadows, open woods, and slopes
Flower Color: Bright red (bracts, not petals)
Native Status: Native to western North America
Interesting Fact: It's a hemiparasite, drawing nutrients from other plants
Best Seen: Dunraven Pass, Hayden Valley
Cultural Note: Considered sacred by several Native American tribes
Habitat: Wet areas, along streams and hot springs
Flower Color: Bright yellow with red spots
Interesting Fact: Can tolerate high mineral content in thermal areas
Growth Habit: Annual or short-lived perennial
Habitat: Meadows, forests, and sagebrush steppe
Interesting Fact: Fixes nitrogen in the soil via root nodules
Best Seen: Open hillsides throughout park
Toxicity: Toxic to livestock if consumed in large quantities
Interesting Fact: Covered in sticky hairs thought to deter herbivores
Best Seen: Forest edges and near streams
Cultural Note: Used in herbal medicine by Native tribes
Flower Color: White to pale lavender
Interesting Fact: One of the first flowers to bloom after snowmelt
Best Seen: Mount Washburn Trail and subalpine zones
Growth Habit: Perennial herb with hairy stems
Post-Bloom: Turns into a fluffy seed head
Flower Color: Deep blue to violet
Interesting Fact: Flowers only open in sunlight
Best Seen: Hayden Valley and Gibbon Meadows
Cultural Note: Known as a symbol of late summer beauty
Habitat: Alpine tundra and rocky slopes
Flower Color: Bright blue with yellow centers
Interesting Fact: Extremely cold-hardy and hugs the ground
Best Seen: Alpine zones near Dunraven Pass
Fun Fact: Official state flower of Alaska
Flower Color: Pink to magenta with reflexed petals
Interesting Fact: Petals point backward like rocket fins
Best Seen: Lamar Valley and Hayden Valley
Interesting Fact: Official state flower of Wyoming
Best Seen: Near Mammoth and Tower areas
Cultural Note: Used in traditional medicine
Flower Color: Sky blue to lavender
Interesting Fact: Flowers turn from pink to blue as they mature
Best Seen: Gibbon River corridor and wet areas
Interesting Fact: Nectar-filled spurs adapted for specialized pollinators
Best Seen: Canyon and Mount Washburn region
Reproduction: Self-seeds readily in favorable conditions
Habitat: Alpine meadows and wet cliffs
Interesting Fact: Emits a skunky smell to deter herbivores
Flower Color: Bright pink to magenta
Interesting Fact: Flowers resemble elephant heads with trunks
Best Seen: Near marshy meadows like Pelican Valley
Cultural Use: Used in herbal medicine by tribes
Flower Color: Lavender with yellow center
Interesting Fact: Named for old belief it repelled fleas
Best Seen: Tower Fall area and north of Mammoth
